facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 92 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Criminal Appeal No. 92 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Cr. Revision Application No. 91 of 1961  by State  companyverted from Cr. A. No. 1131 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1961, of the Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Cr. Revision Application No. 91 of 1961  by State  companyverted from Cr. A. No. 1131 of 1960. Miss Kapila and Y. Kumar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Bombay High Court judgment in Cr. Revision Application No. 91 of 1961 converted from Cr. A. No. 1131 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: of the Bombay High Court in Cr. Revision Application No. 91 of 1961  by State  companyverted from Cr. A. No. 1131 of 1960. Miss Kapila and Y. Kumar, for the appellant. R. Prem, R. H. Dhebar and R. N. Sachthey, for respondent. 1962. September 28.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 28, 1962 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 28. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-In this appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court the question which-arises for companysideration is whether the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, companyld number take companynizance of a companyplaint against the appellant for an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Appellant was a witness for the prosecution in the trial of Rafique Ahmed before the Additional Sessions Judge, Greater Bombay, for offences of murder and abetment of murder.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a witness for the prosecution at the trial of one Rafique Ahmed before the Additional Sessions judge, Greater Bombay, for offences of murder and abetment of murder, along with two other persons.

facts.text: Appellant deposed before the committing magistrate that in his presence Rafique Ahmed had stabbed the deceased Chand while he was running away.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant had been examined as a witness before the companymitting magistrate he deposed that in his presence Rafique Ahmed had stabbed the deceased Chand while he was running away.

facts.text: At the trial before the Court of Sessions three months later, appellant stated he saw Rafique Ahmed and associates coming from burial ground, one with dagger, others sticks, then closed door due to frightened children, disclaimed seeing stabbing.

anchor.surface_text: When, however, he was examined at the trial before the Court of Sessions three months later the appellant stated that while he was standing on the threshold of his house he saw Rafique Ahmed and his two associates companying from the direction of the Muhammaden burial ground. According to him one of them had a dagger while the others had only sticks with them.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge brought out in charge to jury that appellant made two widely divergent statements.

anchor.surface_text: In his charge to the jury the learned Additional Sessions judge who tried the case has brought out the fact that the appellant had made two widely divergent statements in regard to a certain part of the incident.

facts.text: Jury returned verdict of not guilty under s.302 IPC but guilty under s.304 first part for Rafique Ahmed, and guilty under s.304 first part r/w s.109 for other two.

anchor.surface_text: The jury, after companysidering the entire evidence, returned a verdict of number guilty against Rafique Ahmed in respect of the offence under s. 302, I.P.C. but found him guilty under s. 304, first part. It also found the other two accused persons guilty under s. 304, first part, read with s. 109, I. P.C.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge concluded proceedings should be taken against appellant for intentionally giving false evidence and directed Registrar to take steps for prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: After the trial was over the learned Additional Sessions judge came to the companyclusion that proceedings should be taken against the appellant for intentionally giving false evidence. He, therefore, recorded a separate order which runS thus I direct that the Registrar, Sessions Court for Greater Bombay should take necessary steps for prosecution of witness Shabir Hussein Bholu for the offence of perjury

facts.text: Notice issued to appellant to show cause why he should not be prosecuted under s.193 IPC for contradictory statements.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this order a numberice was issued against the appellant requiring him to show cause why he should number be prosecuted under s. 193, I.P.C. for making companytradictory statements regarding the same incident.

facts.text: Appellant appeared before Additional Sessions Judge, counsel submitted contradictory statements due to illiteracy and confusion, contentions rejected, notice made absolute, complaint ordered.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that numberice the appellant appeared before the Additional Sessions Judge and his companynsel submitted that the companytradictory statements were ascribable to the fact that the appellant was illiterate and that his mind was in a state of companyfusion. These companytentions were rejected by the additional Sessions judge who made the numberice absolute and ordered the companyplaint to be filed.

facts.text: Complaint filed under signature of Additional Sessions Judge before Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly a companyplaint was filed under his signature before the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay. The statements which were regarded by him as companytradictory were also set out in that companyplaint.

facts.text: At trial before Chief Presidency Magistrate, objection raised that s.479A CrPC not complied with, cognizance not possible; objection upheld, appellant discharged.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial of the appellant before the Chief Presidency Magistrate an objection was raised on his behalf that the provisions of s. 479-A, Code of Criminal Procedure had number been companyplied with by the Additional Sessions judge and that companysequently the Chief Presidency Magistrate companyld number take companynizance of the offence. The objection was upheld by the Chief Presidency Magistrate and the appellant was ordered to be discharged.

facts.text: State filed revision before Bombay High Court, which granted application, set aside discharge, remanded for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The State preferred an application for revision before the High Court which granted that application, set aside the discharge of the appellant and remanded the case for trial by the Chief Presidency Magistrate.

facts.text: High Court observed that though s.479A not complied with, Magistrate could take action under ss.476-479 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that in its order the High Court has observed that though the provisions of s. 479-A, Cr. P. C. had number been companyplied with, it was still open to the Chief Presidency Magistrate to take action on the companyplaint under ss. 476 to 479 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Chief Presidency Magistrate right in discharging appellant, High Court erred in setting aside.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate was right in discharging the appellant and that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of discharge and directing the Chief Presidency Magistrate to proceed on the basis that the companyplaint was made after following the procedure laid down in ss.

facts.text: Appellant is Shabir Hussein Bholu.

anchor.surface_text: prosecution of witness Shabir Hussein Bholu for the offence of perjury in view of his deposition before the Committing Magistrate and his deposition in this Court, both of which are on oath but are at variance with each other.

facts.text: Deceased in murder case was Chand, possibly referred to as Abu Kana.

anchor.surface_text: He disclaimed knowledge of what happened subsequently and in cross-examination stated that it was number true that he actually saw Rafique Ahmed stabbing the deceased.

facts.text: Committal proceedings are part of the same judicial proceeding as the Sessions trial.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these features which characterise the companymitment proceedings we are of opinion that those proceedings can be regarded as part of the same judicial proceeding which culminated in the decision of the companyrt of Sessions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Prem then companytended that there are two reasons why the provisions of s. 479-A, Cr. P.C. would number apply to the case before us. The first reason, according to him, is that the trial was held by the Additional Sessions judge with the aid of jury and that companysequently there can be numberopportunity to the Additional Sessions judge to record in his judgment a finding of the kind required by s. 479-A  1  and give his reasons for that finding.

issues.text: whether the committal proceedings before the committing magistrate form part of the same judicial proceeding as the sessions trial for the purposes of s. 479A

anchor.surface_text: Now, s. 479- A 1  speaks of false evidence given in any stage of the judicial proceeding. The companymittal proceedings are a stage of the judicial proceedings before the Sessions judge. It seems to us therefore that where false evidence is given before the Committing Magistrate by a person who was later examined at the trial, the evidence given by him before the Committing Magistrate cannot properly be said to have been given in an independent proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate was right in discharging the appellant and that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of discharge and directing the Chief Presidency Magistrate to proceed on the basis that the complaint was made after following the procedure laid down in ss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional Sessions Judge failed to record required finding under s.479A(1) at time of judgment; procedure mandatory and exclusive over ss.476-479

holdings.text: the provisions of ss. 476 to 479 are totally excluded where an offence is of the kind specified in s. 479-A 1

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the view taken in the decisions relied upon by Mr. Prem is not correct and that the view taken in Parshotam Lals case 1 and Amolaks case 2 to the effect that the provisions of ss. 476 to 479 are totally excluded where an offence is of the kind specified in s. 479-A 1 is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause and s.479A(6) make s.479A mandatory and exclusive for intentionally giving false evidence; cannot resort to ss.476-479 later

holdings.text: in a jury trial it is possible for the judge to come to a conclusion that the statement made at the trial is false. If he comes to that conclusion then... he has no option but to proceed under s. 479-A 1

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first point it has to be borne in mind that though it is for the jury to give its verdict regarding the guilt or the innocence of the accused it is open to the Judge to accept or reject the verdict and, therefore, it is necessary for him to record a short judgment either accepting or rejecting the verdict.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judge accepts or rejects jury verdict and records judgment, providing opportunity under s.479A(1); refers under s.307 if rejects

holdings.text: those proceedings can be regarded as part of the same judicial proceeding which culminated in the decision of the Court of Sessions

anchor.surface_text: In view of these features which characterise the commitment proceedings we are of opinion that those proceedings can be regarded as part of the same judicial proceeding which culminated in the decision of the Court of Sessions.

holdings.text: only the provisions of sub- s. 1 of s. 479- A must be resorted to by the Court for the purpose of making a complaint against a person for intentionally giving false evidence or for intentionally fabricating false evidence at any stage of the proceeding before it

anchor.surface_text: Thus bearing in mind the non obstante clause at the commencement of s. 479-A and the provisions of sub-s. 6 , it would follow that only the provisions of sub- s. 1 of s. 479- A must be resorted to by the Court for the purpose of making a complaint against a person for intentionally giving false evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause overrides general provisions; s.479A(6) prohibits proceedings under ss.476-479 if s.479A applicable

precedents.citation: Durga, Prasad Khosla v. The State of U. P. 1

anchor.surface_text: Durga, Prasad Khosla v. The State of U. P. 1 . In that case it was held that s.479-A was enacted to give additional power to the Court authorising it to deal speedily with the more flagrant or serious cases of intentionally giving false evidence or intentionally fabricating evidence in judicial proceedings.

precedents.case_name: Durga Prasad Khosla v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: s.479-A enacted to give additional power for flagrant or serious cases of perjury or fabrication of evidence; less serious cases under s.476; no implied repeal of s.476
precedents.cited_holding: s.479-A was enacted to give additional power to the Court authorising it to deal speedily with the more flagrant or serious cases of intentionally giving false evidence or intentionally fabricating evidence in judicial proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Lal Behari v. State 2  where the same view was taken. The learned judges who decided the case dissented from the view taken in Jaibir Singh v. Malkhan Singh 3  to the effect that s. 479-A was a companyplete companye in itself for dealing with all offences which fall within its ambit.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.479-A provides additional procedure for serious perjury cases; s.476 still available for less serious

anchor.surface_text: Jaibir Singh v. Malkhan Singh 3  to the effect that s. 479-A was a companyplete companye in itself for dealing with all offences which fall within its ambit. Learned companynsel further relied on the decision in Badullah State 4  where it was held that the provisions of ss. 476 and 479-A are number companyextensive

precedents.cited_proposition: s.479-A is a complete code in itself for dealing with all offences which fall within its ambit

anchor.surface_text: Badullah State 4  where it was held that the provisions of ss. 476 and 479-A are number companyextensive and s. 479-A was added in ch. XXXV with the intention of arming the Courts with another weapon with which to deal with the growing evil of perjury in a more effective manner.

precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of ss.476 and 479-A are not co-extensive; s.479-A added as additional weapon against perjury

precedents.citation: state of Bombay v. Premdas Sukritdas Chadhewal Koshti 1

anchor.surface_text: state of Bombay v. Premdas Sukritdas Chadhewal Koshti 1  in which it was held that s. 479-A does number companytain an exhaustive and self-contained procedure relating to all classes of perjury but only applies to a case where the Court acts suo motu at the time of declaring its judgment

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v Premdas Sukritdas Chadhewal Koshti
precedents.cited_proposition: s.479-A not exhaustive for all perjury, only for serious flagrant cases where finding recorded at judgment time; s.476 for other cases; sub-s.6 does not exclude from 476-479
precedents.cited_holding: s. 479-A does number companytain an exhaustive and self-contained procedure relating to all classes of perjury but only applies to a case where the Court acts suo motu at the time of declaring its judgment and records a finding

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam, Lal v. Madan Lal 2  where it was held that the provisions of s. 479-A override the provisions of ss. 476 to 479 in so far as they relate to the giving of false evidence or fabricating false evidence by a person who gives evidence during the companyrse of the judicial proceedings.

precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of s.479-A override ss.476-479 for offences of giving or fabricating false evidence in judicial proceedings before the court
precedents.cited_holding: the provisions of s. 479-A override the provisions of ss. 476 to 479 in so far as they relate to the giving of false evidence or fabricating false evidence by a person who gives evidence during the course of the judicial proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Amolak v. State 3  where more or less the same view was taken and it was further pointed out that where a case is of a class which falls squarely within the ambit of s. 479-A 1  of the Code, the provisions of s. 476 to s. 479 are inapplicable.

precedents.cited_proposition: where case falls within ambit of s.479-A(1), provisions of ss.476-479 inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the view taken in the decisions relied upon by Mr. Prem is not correct and that the view taken in Parshotam Lals case 1 and Amolaks case 2 to the effect that the provisions of ss. 476 to 479 are totally excluded where an offence is of the kind specified in s. 479-A 1 is correct.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first point it has to be borne in mind that though it is for the jury to give its verdict regarding the guilt or the innocence of the accused it is open to the Judge to accept or reject the verdict and, therefore, it is necessary for him to record a short judgment either accepting or rejecting the verdict.

For these reasons we hold that the learned Chief Presidency Magistrate was right in discharging the appellant and that the High Court was in error in setting aside the order of discharge and directing the Chief Presidency Magistrate to proceed on the basis that the complaint was made after
